“Are we there yet?” whined Alan and Megan, in unison.

Eyes still firmly focused on the dark highway ahead, their father Steve answered without turning his head to see the kids in the backseat.

“Not yet,” he said in a dull, tired monotone.

“Kids, please be quiet,” sighed Janet, the mother of this family. “You know we're still at least two or three hours from home. If we hadn't had to take that lengthy detour from construction, we'd be there by now. Just be patient. We're all tired and eager to finally sleep at home in our own beds.”

Janet was a pear-shaped, middle aged woman who had once upon a time been a high school prom queen and captain of the cheerleader squad. Although her face was still attractive and she carried herself with the graceful poise of a professional woman of the world, Janet had acquired a heavier, more rounded body over the years. Her once champagne colored hair was now dishwater blonde. Faint wrinkles now lined her eyes. Two pregnancies had widened her hips and swollen her breasts, while years of a sedentary lifestyle had added padding to her ass and thighs.

Alan, age fifteen, sighed impatiently and turned his attention back to a hand-held video game he'd been toying with all day long. He never thought he'd get bored with it, but after being cooped up in the family car for so long, he found himself eager to do something... anything else! Alan was normally an athletic, outgoing teenager who was active in sports, had lots of friends, and regularly had a pretty girlfriend he was dating. Although he enjoyed video games like any other teenage boy, he wasn't a stereotypical gamer geek.

Megan, age twelve, got out her ipod for the umpteenth time today, popped the ear buds in each ear, and started re-listening to the same songs she'd been amusing herself with all afternoon. Megan was a very self-conscious preteen girl, embarrassed by her braces, her stick thin figure, and the occasional zit on her perpetually over made-up face. Where Alan was successful at fitting in socially, Megan hadn't yet “found herself,” and remained in that nebulously ambiguous no man's land of social awkwardness between childhood and adolescence.

Steve Donaldson looked over his family through the rear-view mirror of the car. He was a tired, paunchy, easily irritated man. Steve worked as in middle-management for a big insurance company – work he found to be monotonous and uninspiring... but at least it paid the bills. Just like Janet, he had let himself go over the years with regards to his physique. Where once he had been strong and athletic like Alan, now Steve was soft and doughy with a pasty complexion, a rapidly receding hairline, and a slowly expanding pot belly.

Just then, the concentration of the entire Donaldson family was harshly interrupted by a sudden loud, sickening, dull explosion.

“Shit, we just blew a tire!” yelled Steve, hammering his fist down on the steering wheel.

“Well, just pull over,” said Janet, striving hard to remain the cool and calm voice of reason. “We have a spare. You can change it.”

“It's pitch black out there,” grumbled Steve, parking the car on the shoulder of the road. “I'm not changing a damn tire in the middle of the night in the middle of nowhere!”

“Well, we can't just sit here until morning,” protested Janet.

“Hey, guys...” Alan started to say.

“Be quiet!” snapped Steve. “Now... I guess I could call for a tow truck.”

“I don't think so, honey,” muttered Janet. “I've been trying to get a signal on my phone for the last twenty minutes. We're in some weird dead zone out here.”

“Dammit, you're right,” grumbled Steve fiddling with his own phone.

“But guys...” said Alan again.

“Alan, not now!” snapped Steve.

“No, listen Dad,” protested Alan. “There's a house right off the road. I can see it from here. Just look!”

Steve and Janet squinted into the darkness.

Sure enough, just a few yards off the dark, lonesome highway, there stood the shadowy silhouette of a tall, Victorian style mansion... utterly isolated and looking eerily out-of-place.

“Do you think anybody lives here?” asked Megan.

“Who would live out here?” wondered Janet. “I don't see anything else out there – no other houses, barns, or anything.”

“I don't even see the driveway,” said Steve. “Even assuming there's somebody home and they have a telephone we could use... How do we get there?”

“Just walk through the ditch on the side of the road,” said Alan. “Hop that little fence, and we're practically in their front yard.”

A cold shiver suddenly ran down the spines of each member of the Donaldson family. Then, wordlessly, they each exited the car and did just as Alan had suggested. In less than five minutes, the family stood at the front door of the old mansion. It loomed much larger over them now, bigger than it had seemed from the relative safety of the family car back up on the highway.

“Well...” said Steve. “I guess I'd better knock, I suppose.”

He loudly rapped his fist against the heavy, wooden door. The sound of his quick, staccato knocking echoed in the dark, still night, air. The family stood, shivering quietly, for a moment.

“I don't think anyone lives here,” said Janet.

“Let's just go inside,” suggested Megan. “Dad can change the tire in the morning. We'll just camp out here for the night.”

“We can't just go inside,” said Steve. “That's called trespassing and...”

Before he could finish his thought, Janet had turned the knob on the front door and opened up a dark, gaping maw in the house. Warm, dry air wafted from inside the building, almost inviting the family in.

“It isn't locked,” said Janet.

“Dad, let's just go in,” said Alan.

“Fine,” said Steve. “Just don't touch anything. No snooping or vandalizing anything. The owners might just be away right now.”

Janet, Alan, and Megan nodded in agreement... and followed Steve into the mysterious house.

“Guess we'd better get dressed in... uh... our new clothes,” said Alan.

“You're my teenage son – not a grown woman,” said Steve. “I don't want you wearing your mother's clothes again.”

“Oh, get over it Steven,” snapped Janet. “He'll look like a damned idiot running all over town dressed like a teenage boy. Despite the way we see ourselves right now, everyone else seems to think we're each other. I don't want people thinking he's me, and then wondering why Janet Donaldson is running errands while wearing her son's clothes.”

“No,” said Steve. “We're not falling into this trap. That's what... what... that stupid book wants us to do, don't you see?”

“Uh huh,” said Janet, rolling her eyes. “The book wants us to wear each other's clothes?”

“The book did this to us!” replied Steve. “Unless we fight back and refuse to cooperate, the book wins! It switched all our identities around – God knows why – and then wants us to fall further and further into the trap of acting like each other. I'm not Megan! That might be what I see in the mirror, but it's not me! And even if the rest of the planet sees me as her, I'm not going to wear Megan's clothes.”

“You already are,” laughed Megan, pointing at her father's girlish pajamas.

“Correction then – I'm not going to wear them any longer,” said Steve.

“Maybe Dad has a point,” Alan said gently. “We've all been acting a little odd lately.”

“It's just the shock and stress of all this weirdness,” said Janet.

“I think it's more than that,” Alan replied. “Maybe we ought to struggle more against... oh, I don't know... against feeling too comfortable in these new roles? Surely our first priority has to be finding a way of changing back.”

If we all play hooky to stay home and clutch desperately at straws, then your father will get fired and you kids will get detention. We'll work on studying that book later tonight. Stephen thought. "OK, so let's all get this straight. I think I'm a man named Stephen but you all think I'm Stephanie. You're Gene, but you think of yourself as Janet. Alison thinks of herself as a jock boy named Alan, and Marvin thinks he's a twelve year old girl named Megan."

Everyone shook their heads in confused agreement.

"OK, so this means that the book, whatever it is, altered our perceptions differently for each of us. We each see things a little differently from one another, but we don't know which is the right perception. Everybody take any kind of identification."

Stephen reached for his wallet and found his picture and identification to be that of his given name, Stephen Donaldson. His DOB, gender, height, weight and otherwise were all correct.

Janet reached for her purse, but remembered that she left it in the car. However, she did have a tattoo on her right thigh from when she first got engaged that said Janet Hearts Stephanie. She lifted her leg and showed it to her wife, who only in his mind saw it as Gene Hearts Stephen.

"It says Gene loves Stephen, love."

Janet lifted up her thigh behind her to look, but saw the exact opposite.

Alan reached for his school identification from last semester, as did Megan for hers. Both ID's confirmed to themselves that they were indeed Alan Donaldson and Megan Donaldson, but when they showed their ID's to each other, Megan saw Alan's picture as that of a smiling photogenic blonde girl named Alison Donaldson and Alan saw Megan's picture as that of a gangly, somewhat nerdy middle-school boy named Marvin Donaldson.

"Mom, our ID's don't prove anything. We each see something different" whined Megan

"I'm not your mom!" barked Stephen. "Would you look at her thigh for me. What does it say, Marvin?"

"My name's Megan" she huffed, then looked down at her father's right thigh.

"It says Gene Hearts Stephanie, mom."

Both parents shouted "What are talking about?" in unison.

Alan stepped forward and confirmed that he saw it as Gene Hearts Stephanie too.

"I think it's a little weird that a guy would get a heart tattoo" said Alan. "Maybe our dad really is our mom, and since mom seems so aggressive, she might really be our dad."

The tired, thoroughly confused family of four followed Steve's orders and made their way out of the spooky house and downwards towards the car. Once inside the car, they locked all the doors.

"Gotcha."

Steve dreamed that night...whatever it was he dreamed about, this writer can't say. But he was awakened by his daughter at around 5:00 A.M, just as twilight was in it's last throws and was soon to give way to dawn.

"Mom, dad, whoever you are, there's a State Trooper outside!" said Ally.

"Huh?" Steve muttered, and then looked over to see a flashlight being pointed in his face. He opened the door to go outside.

"Miss, this area is considered unsafe due to a recent string of disappearances." The patrolman then gave a quick glance behind him towards the house they vacated. "I see that your tire is blown. Would you like me to call you a tow truck?"

"No, that's fine. I have a spare in my trunk. I can get it taken care of." Steve grimaced a little at the "Miss" comment, but didn't say anything.

"OK then. Just be careful and vigilant."

"I will."

The officer nodded and then went back to his bike and sped off.

When the officer was out of sight, Steve knocked on Ally's door for assistance. She got out the door and followed him to the trunk.

"Get the tire iron and jack out, will you?"

"Sure thing."

Father and daughter...Mother and son...father and son...whatever they were, the two got the tire on in about four and a half minutes. The emerging sunlight helped.

"What time is it, Ally?"

"It's Alan, and it's 5:20 A.M."

"Alan" Steve nodded.

Both of them got back in the car. Steve started the ignition, and began the rest of the drive home.

"You know, that patrolman called you "Miss" said Alan. "Shouldn't that settle it that you're really my mom and not a man?"

"Oh, and what if he referred to you as a girl? Would you be comfortable with that?!"

Alan shut up and went to sleep.

A few hours later, the Donaldson family made it back to their Tudor style house in their comfortable, middle class neighborhood. As the car pulled into the driveway, Janet started to awaken.

"Oh honey, I just had this awful dream where we went into this haunted house, and you and Ally thought you were both men, and Marvin thought he was a boy!"

"It wasn't a dream, Gene!" Steve shouted. "That house and that book were real. We're in a real pile of shit here."

"Oh, you all still think I'm a boy still don't you?" Megan moaned. "I wish it was all a dream too."

"Well it isn't. We all have to deal with it until we find a solution. Gene, I want you to use your phone. Call up one of your friends, and notice how they respond to you."

"OK, sure thing" Janet answered. She decided to call her friend Lindy.

"Lindy? Oh hey, it's Janet. Yeah, we just got back from vacation. What's that? We took the kids to Bluffington to visit some relatives, then we went to Funkytown. Yeah, it was wonderful, a lot of fun. Stephanie? She's doing fine, how's Brandon? Good, and yes, the kids loved it as far as I can tell. Do you want to talk to Stephanie?"

Steve made a hand gesture indicating that he didn't want to talk to Lindy right now.

Janet went back on the phone. "I guess she doesn't want to talk. No, she's not butch or anything, Stephanie is just a bit of a misanthrope. Ohmigod, you heard what?! No..."

Steve got out of the car before he was infected by the gossip. He needed a good stiff drink and some sleep. He fished the keys out of his pocket and opened the door.

He couldn't believe it, there was no way out. Was everyone going to call him "Stephanie" and think he was a woman for the rest of his life? And what about the way Gene was acting. He was totally out of character. Under normal circumstances, no one would ever confuse either Gene or Steve with the media stereotype of gay men. Neither of them were camp, neither were promiscuous in front of others or talked about sex in polite conversation and both were good providers for their kids. And now this stupid curse or whatever it was threw it all out the window, with Gene having effete mannerisms. After drinking a quick beer, Steve went upstairs to get some needed sleep.

Megan entered the house shortly thereafter, just as worried as her mom(dad?) was. Using her computer to check Facebook, she was relieved when her profile was exactly how she remembered it. There were pictures of her hanging out with her friends, as a girl and not as a boy, and no-one called her "Marvin"...whoever the heck that was.

"Ally! No wait, Alan! Come quick! There's something I want to show you!"

Alan walked into the house shortly, with Janet still in the car on the phone.

"Look! This proves I'm a girl. I typed in a post a minute ago, and Ashley referred to me as "Megan", not "Marvin"! See, other people still see that I'm a girl!"

"That's weird" said Alan. "I can see where they call you Megan, but your name in the heading still shows your name as Marvin. And I still see your picture as of a boy."

Megan's face soured. "OK, I'll check your profile." She signed out, and handed the tablet to her not-sister.

Alan signed in with his e-mail address and password, which to him showed his name as Alan Donaldson and with a few, much less than Megan, pictures of himself either at school, on the field, or with friends.

"Ask your girlfriend a question, see what she says."

Alan did so, and shortly got a response that referred to him as "Alan", but when he showed it to Megan, she predictably saw Alan's picture and name heading as those of the mysterious Alison. His girlfriend confirmed that his name was Alan, but everywhere else suggested otherwise.

"What did that curse do to us?" Megan wondered.

Apparently 'Stephanie' is even more curvy than you are, but it's the best you can do other than going to the thrift story. Lord knows Ally would never let you try on her clothes."

"Ally seems really convinced that she's a boy though and won't wear any of her stuff now. It's Marvin you have to worry about."

"I've explained to Marvin that even if he see's himself as the opposite sex, nobody else does, and that he'll get beaten up for wearing girls clothing outside the house. Ally can get away with being tomboyish, but a boy acting girly in public is not acceptable. If he wants to dress that way in his own room, fine, but no where else."

The subject abruptly changed.

"Do you really think that we should go back to that house?" Janet asked.

"If you ever want to get back to normal, yes. Something happened there, but we were unprepared and walked right into a trap. Now we have to fix it."

"OK. Call me when you have a chance". Janet then hugged Steve warmly, and kissed him.

"You be good now."

"I will" smiled Steve.

He then walked to the car and went to work.

The commute was normal, the parking was ample, and while stepping into the building, Steve didn't notice any female reflection looking back at him reflected off the glass or off the polished surfaces like he had feared. All he saw was good old Steve. The work day required no gender-disparity politics that Steve could notice. Everyone, either in person, on the phone, on the computer or at the water cooler, all called Steve by his given name and seemed to think of him as a guy. This contradicted the State Trooper a few days ago who referred to him as a "Miss". At the lunch period, Steve went outside and called up his wife(for the sake of Gene, he called him his wife) to tell him the good(but peculiar) news update:

"Hey Gene, you won't believe the news. Nobody thinks I'm a woman. Nobody. Everybody think that I'm Steve."

"That's a little strange" said Janet. "Talking to the neighbors, they all think of you as Stephanie. I have some strange news of my own. Some of them remember Ally, but others remember Alan, and some remember Marvin, but others swear that we have a twelve year old girl named Megan. Ally has had trouble around her friends because they see her one way or the other, and the same goes for Marvin."

This spoiled Steve's perfect (work) day.

"Damn it. What about the book from the house, The Book Of Life Changes? Any word on that yet?"

"Yes. I found someone who's a paranormal detective."

"Ah fuck, don't tell me you fell for a scam like that Gene."

"I looked for his phone number and called him up. He's completely free until the case is solved to our satisfaction, and he lives right in the city, so we can either go to him or he can come to us. He doesn't sound like a fraud. Sure, he's probably a fake, but he's not asking for money, so it can't hurt right, honey?"

"Not exactly, Gene. It's a waste of my time, and time these days is a resource I don't want to waste. But since I'm not good with these things in the first place, I leave the ball in your court. Gene?"

"Yes babe?"

"What's the guy's name?"

"Mr. E. He goes by an alias."

"Mr. E? Wasn't he a comic book character? I could swear he was. I known I've heard that name before..."

"It's not exactly original, but all the original names were taken" laughed Janet.

"So when do you want to see him?"

"Tonight" said Janet. "It's spookier that way. Ooooo...."

14533122222.content:

At the end of the day, Megan and Alan returned home from school, arriving at virtually the same time. Much to Janet's consternation, both greeted her by saying, “Hi, Dad!”

“How was school, kids?” asked Janet.

“Not too bad,” answered Alan. He was dressed in very unisex fashion – a pair of jeans, tennis shoes, and a plain, black t-shirt. Janet noted with disapproval that he wasn't wearing a bra, but she chose to say nothing, knowing he perceived himself as male while she still saw him as a teenage girl.

“Don't get me wrong, dad,” continued Alan. “School today was pretty weird at moments. I know you all think I'm some girl named 'Alison,' but practically everybody at school still sees me as Alan – a guy. The only weird part was gym class. I tried to change clothes in the boys locker room, but got in trouble and they kicked me out. So for that one class, I got treated like a girl. Everyone called me 'Ally,' and I had to change in the girls locker, and I had to wear a sports bra and everything.”

Alan paused and shuddered with disgust.

“But,” he continued. “After gym class, everything went back to normal and all my friends and teachers saw me as Alan again. Marvin says he had a pretty similar day too, didn't you?”

Megan looked very frustrated and embarrassed at being dressed in boys clothes: basically the same jeans and t-shirt ensemble Alan wore. But she nodded her head and agreed about the strangely routine way her day had gone.

“Ally's right,” said Megan. “All my friends see me as Megan still. A bunch of them were all like, 'why are you dressed like such a tomboy' and I got made fun of a bit, 'cuz I'm not wearing lipstick and my hair looks like I just rolled out of bed. But other than that, it was all just like Ally said. The only time anybody thought I was a boy named 'Marvin' was in health class. We're doing sex-ed, y'know? And they made me sit in a room full of boys and learn about erections and prostates and... ewww... just all kinds of gross out stuff!”

“Well, you are at that age,” said Janet. “You're becoming a young man, and...”

“Dad, I'm a girl!” protested Megan.

“Okay, okay,” sighed Janet. “Have it your way.”

“Tell Dad about the other thing,” urged Alan.

“Awwww, why did you have to bring that up?” asked Megan.

“What's the 'other thing'?” asked Janet.

“After school, I met up with Allison,” said Megan. “And while we were walking home, some other girls came up to us, and they were all laughing and stuff, and one of them said... she said she liked me.”

“And then she kissed him on the cheek!” said Alan. “Marvin's got a girlfriend!”

“I am a girl! Just like you, Ally!” protested Megan.

“Ally, Marvin – Please!” said Janet, trying to broker the peace between the bickering siblings. “But... Well, since the two of you brought up the obvious topic – your mother and I are meeting with a paranormal investigator this evening...”

“A what?” asked Alan.

“It's like a detective who specializes in weird, unexplained stuff, sweetie,” answered Janet. “His name is Mister E, and since all of us have been affected in some way by what happened in that... that... that creepy house...”

“You want us to meet with this private eye, too?” asked Alan.

“Well, yes I do,” answered Janet. “I want my entire family to stick together until we get this whole paranormal confusion resolved. Once your mother gets home from work, we'll have dinner... and then we're supposed to meet Mister E at his office, after dusk.”

“You really think he can help us, Dad?” whined Megan.

“At this point, Marvin, all we have is hope,” sighed Janet.

What next?

After dinner, the Donaldson family did indeed go to Mister E's office.

"This is the bad part of town" said Steve. "Great." He wondered what was going to happen to the car while they were inside.

Everyone got out, walked up to the glass door with the Mystery Machine from "Scooby Doo" on it, and rang the buzzer. A man walked out of the shadow's, and rang a second buzzer attached to the wall to let them inside. Steve entered, holding the door open for Janet, Megan, and Alan.

"Isn't there any electricity in here" asked an annoyed Steve.

"Yes. There is." Mister E then turned on the lights casually.

The family got a good look at Mister E. Janet and Megan both thought that he could be attractive if he had better posture and his skin wasn't so pale. He was youngish, late twenties or maybe early thirties, tall, brown hair, and judging by his biceps he obviously worked out. He wore a fedora reminiscent of Indiana Jones, and a billowing black coat.

Looking around the office, there were posters on the wall of various famous detectives, everyone from Sherlock Holmes to Columbo to various cartoon detectives.

"Hello. I am Mister E." His voice was low and strangely awkward. Steve was convinced that they have run into a crackpot, or even worse, a crackhead.

Janet reacted first. "I'm Janet Donaldson. We spoke on the phone."

"YYYess" he drawled. "You went to the dilapidated Cameron Manor, opened a book with a greenish glow to it, and now you've all lost your memories. I recall the chat we...had."

"Can you help us?" asked Alan. "We all see ourselves differently then how everyone else does. I see myself as a guy, but everyone else thinks I'm a girl named Ally. My name's Alan by the way. Marvin thinks he's a girl named Megan, my mom thinks he's a man, and my dad thinks he's a woman. And some people perceive us as one or the other. Like some people see me as Alan, but others swear that I'm Ally. And when we got home, all of our clothing was different. And our identification is different too. I went on Facebook, with an account that I set up for myself under the name Alan, but it says Allison instead. But when I talk to people there or in real life, they usually see me as Alan."

Megan shook her head in agreement. "It's the same story with me." Steve acknowledged that, yes, it's happened to him too.

"Hmm..." said Mister E. "The Book Of Life Changes usually doesn't act this way. It usually alters just alters reality, but this case..."

"You all look exactly as you claim to be." He point at Steve. "You're a man, not a woman. I know that you work in insurance, and your average yearly salary is-", and then the detective pointed all the way down the line, explaining what he saw in each person.

"Wait" said Janet. "This is my wife. I'm gay, not straight. I met Stephie in college. Are you telling me that my memories are wrong?"

"Yes" said Mister E. "Your memories have been altered by the Book Of Life Changes. It came into this dimension in the year 541 B.C.E in Australia."

"What?!" exclaimed Megan.

"It's a magic book used to alter people, as you can tell by the name. There was a collector of extra-dimensional artifacts who used to live in that house named Cameron. He and his wife left under mysterious circumstances, I'm still looking into it, but they left their library of magic books behind."

"So this means...that I really am a girl and not a boy?" asked Megan.

"Yes and no. You are all confusing yourselves and being confused with your parallel universe's counterparts. There are several versions of a boy named Marvin Donaldson who fills your role. I spoke to one of the alternate universe Donaldson's this morning. They were just as confused as you were."

Steve looked at Mister E with trepidation and a large dose of skepticism. "I'm guessing you didn't help them yet."

Mister E responded "Not yet. It will take a few days to fix everything and stopped the various continuities from bleeding into each other. You know, my deductive abilities are a lot sharper when I'm not hungry. Would you all like to go to dinner with me? There's a diner nearby, and I'll pay."

Not having much other choice, the Donaldson family agreed to follow Mister E to a nearby diner. He selected a real greasy spoon place. The staff all greeted him as though he were a regular.

“The food here is delicious,” said Mister E, settling into a booth and gesturing for the family to join him. “Please – do sit down and enjoy yourselves. As I said, dinner is on me.”

The family reluctantly climbed into the restaurant booth and each of them ordered something from the friendly waitress who hovered about them, calling everyone “sugar” or “honey.”

“So, let's get back to business,” said Steve. “Mister E – you said it'll take a few days to put everything right?”

“That's correct,” replied the mysterious private investigator. “You were all affected by the Book of Life Changes – a powerful artifact that has never, to my knowledge, behaved quite this way before. Had your curse been a little more run-of-the-mill, I could reverse it much more easily. But to disentangle so many different parallel realities... well, it is tedious, difficult, time-consuming work, Mister Donaldson.”

“I wish you wouldn't treat Stephie like she's a man,” complained Janet. “It's all so weird hearing you call her 'Mister Donaldson' and all.”

“But I am a man,” said Steve. “And you're my gay partner Gene – not... not... this frumpy housewife you seem to think you are.”

“Please, everyone, please,” sat Mister E gently, waving his hands in the air for effect. “Settle down for a moment.”

The family grew silent and patiently waited for the detective to continue.

“As I said, I can and will correct everything,” continued Mister E. “But are you all prepared for that? If we go down this route, in two or three days I will have reality straightened out... and you will all be Steve, Janet, Megan, and Alan. You'll each be the person you remember being – but the rest of your family will no longer be the people you currently mis-remember them as.”

“You're saying our memories are all wrong?” asked Alan.

“Yes,” answered Mister E. “To a certain extant. Each of you recalls your own identities correctly. But you – and certain random other people in the world – each see the rest of the family and your relationships to them... well... incorrectly. After I put things right, most of your memories should return to normal. But quite frankly, there is no guarantee that everything you remember will 'snap' back to the way it was before.”

Mister E turned to Steve and Janet.

“You two will become a male and female heterosexual couple,” said Mister E. “Are you prepared for that? It's what you used to be, prior to your run-in at the Cameron House. What I cannot guarantee is that everything about your private memories and personalities will be properly restored. It is possible you will see each other normally, but Steve will remain a gay man and Janet will remain a lesbian. I just want to prepare you for this distinct possibility.”

“Well, since I am a gay man,” said Steve. “I won't mind that. But I have to admit, it sounds strange to hear I'll be married to a woman. And a lesbian one at that!”

“But we'd all agree on how we see each other?” asked Janet. “I mean, even if some of our memories remain a little goofed up, we'd all agree on what we see? And we'd still be a family, right?”

“Absolutely,” replied Mister E. “You and the rest of the world will go back to seeing one another as Steve, Janet, Alan, and Megan. There's just a certain possibility of a few old memories lingering or some small personality changes from before the accident. Now, is this what you want me to do?”

What next?
